text: Neatly portrayed, colorful. waves well delineated.

text: I'm really impressed by attention to details clearly visible on this part of 1-8 screen. Here we have a small sailing boat - part of larger group of American warships. One could easily guess what this small boat purpose is within a formation.

text: The blandness of the weather seems deliberate. The pale sky and the barely there blue ocean force the viewer to focus on the ships. The realistic depiction of the ships in the left two panels gives a sense of size, depth and motion of the ships. The third panel (which I agree is probably done by a diff. artist) is a flat rendering but with great detail given to all the ships staff, rigging, masts, etc... To me all these things make me feel that this scroll was probably used for study by scholars and Feudal leaders.

text: Looking through, it is evident that the ships were of greater importance to the artist than the people manning them. That is why there is such minute detail in even the masts and the way the water moves under the boat and its equipment.

text: The sailor's faces and bodies all look the same. They are neither shown in a positive light or negative one. In fact, many of them do not have full faces (obviously because they are too far away to make out any features) but I still find it interesting that they are depicted this way.

text: I was surprised by the amount of detail; however, in order to display the most accurate information about the ships and personnel, it was necessary to be detailed. These pictures could be used as references for actual reproduction. The perspective used for the side wheel seems a little "off," but in this way the artist could show more of the important structural detail. The details which were of lesser inportance to the Japanese were not so accurate, as in the case of the American flag.

text: I find it interesting that these flags were drawn in this position. It stands out so much against the black smoke. Maybe it portrayed what the artist felt about the fleet of Americans. Also gives me a feeling of dread.

text: Calm weather all around but for me this feels a bit intimidating owing to the fact that everything is bland. Even the skies, beautiful as they were during a gorgeous Japanese day, is devoid of any clouds or even the regular blue you usually see. Makes the painting seem lifeless but the animation provided by the ships contrasts with the underlying 'quietness' of the images.

text: The depictions appear more objective now that communication and some understanding between the two contingents have taken place.  Gone are the menacing demonic faces on the bow and stern, the portrayal of evil or threat.  These are impressive ships, yes, but just naval ships with naval staff doing their work.  The detail in illustrating the ropes, masts, those openings on the sides of the ships, the smaller boats, the billowing smoke, and everything really is impressive.  I've enjoyed looking at this row of images in detail.  I notice a couple of seemingly special bright red rowing boats - I wonder why they are red, are they for high ranking officers only?  The lines in the ocean waves and charcoal smoke makes me think how oriental in style it is.  Wonderful illustration.

text: All the American boats show lots of industry, many sailors at work. But the scale isn't quite right, so there's a sense that they've been added to emphasize the size of these ships, especially when compared to Japanese ships. It must be the equivalent of an aircraft carrier appearing in Boston Harbor: fascinating, enormous, filled with life, and lots of detail.

text: I just feel this wheel was drawn to be very interesting. The upper is something very technical and the part under this technical machin is drawn like a traditional wheel. They were drawned to be very detailed. And it shows that the Japanese were trying to understand how the ship worked.

text: I like the realism of the sailors scurrying about the rigging, doing whatever it is that sailors did on a ship in those days. I like how accurate the rigging looks too, it seems true to form to my untrained eyes.

text: This drawing represents the pollution, the contamination caused by US Navy when they came in contact with the Japanese. This contact, for the Japanese, can also be seen as an act of contamination, as they "contaminated" the foreign culture with their costume and may also have altered traditions

text: Men at the top of the rendition mean the control and ruling of humanity over their own creations. Time has proved this to be false, since there are also many problems caused by misuse of technology. But at this moment it was a time of raving optimism,

They couldn't help throwing in a "perfect" profile shot, could they?

Is this flag innaccurate, or merely a flag I was no able to find? I attempted to find the flag by searching US Naval flags and other versions of the US flag at the time of his voyage, but was unable to find it.

It seems odd to me because it's so consistently reproduced with this look, and this particular patterning of the stars seems overly complicated for a "misrepresentation" by a foreigner who couldn't accurately reproduce the pattern. Indeed, all patterns I found at this time are simply than this one.

text: As an English student I was surprised to see this unusual arrangement of the stars on the American Flag on what seems to be a well observed and deatiled painting. I was even more surpised to find that many variations were used over time (and not necessarily because of new States joing the Union). The screen uses this arrangement on others ships, is it likely to be correct? If not why not? the artist has clearly observed the fleet.

text: The ships are depicted in great detail, they are shown really realistically, and you can also see ships in depth as well as the patterns of the waves formed in the sea around them. But there are no drawings of birds or fish or mammals that should normally show on a realistic drawing. Thus, these drawings show up really detailed and realistic, but they are not made to fill in the curiosity of Japanese; they seem to be made to carefully describe the technological gap they had from Americans at the time when Commodore Perry showed up in Japan. So this looks like an instructive collection of American ships in an attempt to remember them so that they can build their own.

text: The American Flags look like accurate. I am very curious about the depiction of them. As misterspock1 mentioned, they have to have 31 stars (California was the newest state at that time) and 13 stripes even this flag has 14 stripes. The Japanese painters would make them (at least one depiction of a flag) if they knew the history of the “Stars and Stripes”.

text: The ship’s black steam purposedly painted in the central part of the byobu, juxtaposed with the colourful American flags give, by contrast, dramaticity and main focus to the depiction. text: The men are dwarfed by the ship. Perhaps this helps to illustrate the technological might wielded by what were seen as otherwise very human (described by the Japanese in ways indicating they were seen as kind, foolish, jovial, etc). The ships are more a part of the landscape, forces of natural power, than they are connected with humanity and its tools.

text:
Here I was struck by the variation in U.S. flags as depicted on these panels of the screen. 4 flags have a large star in the upper corner and a group of smaller stars, and one flag has uniformly sized stars. Did Perry fly different versions of the U.S. flag or are these just different interpretations of the same flag by the Japanese? The 31-star flag became the official U.S. flag on July 4, 1851, a star having been added to mark the statehood of California (Sept 9, 1850). This 31-star flag was the flag flown for 7 years (1851-1858), so it was the flag Perry sailed under.

 

Japanese images of American flags on the screen show fewer stars, eg., 9 stars, or 16 plus one big star (1), 14 plus one big star (2). There are usually 14 or 13 stripes (a white one added on the bottom), so the observation of stripes was close to accurate. Could the same be true of the number of stars? Stars are harder to depict and fit into a small space. But do the four flags depicted with one big star in the upper corner in addition to the array of small ones reflect a real flag used by the fleet?

 

There was a 31-star American flag that had a big white star, but in the middle of a squarish field of 30 smaller ones. The big star represented the recently added state of California. The basic pattern of this flag is the Trumbull Flag, used by the Navy during the War of Independence and from around 1778 to 1880. The original Trumbull pattern was thirteen stars for the original colonies, one star larger and in the middle, seen in Revolutionary War paintings by John Trumbull. This original 13-star pattern is also seen in paintings of American ships of the early and mid-19th century, flying from the mast and flagstaffs.

 

But the flags on the screen do not depict the big star as being in the middle. So, the Japanese image could be an interpretation of the 1853 Commodore Perry flag, which has 31 stars: a square 5x5 grid with a leftmost column of 6, to make up 31. The topmost star on the leftmost column, by standing above the other stars at the top may have seemed unusually prominent, especially rippling in the wind, and thus depicted as larger than the rest. The usual 31-star flag of the time was also arranged in a way that could have had the effect of making the stars at either end of the topmost row seem unusually prominent because they were surrounded by more blue.

 

However, the flags depicted on the Todai screen with one big star have close to 13 smaller ones, and the same pattern of stars and blue space, which leads me to wonder if the Japanese artist is perhaps depicting a variant original Trumbull pattern flag used by the Navy in Perry’s time. The ships are depicted so meticulously that this seems possible. Also, Trumbull flags were often flown from the stern, and this is the case with the four flags here.

text:
Here I was struck by the variation in U.S. flags as depicted on these panels of the screen. 4 flags have a large star in the upper corner and a group of smaller stars, and one flag has uniformly sized stars. Did Perry fly different versions of the U.S. flag or are these just different interpretations of the same flag by the Japanese? The 31-star flag became the official U.S. flag on July 4, 1851, a star having been added to mark the statehood of California (Sept 9, 1850). This 31-star flag was the flag flown for 7 years (1851-1858), so it was the flag Perry sailed under.

 

Japanese images of American flags on the screen show fewer stars, eg., 9 stars, or 16 plus one big star (1), 14 plus one big star (2). There are usually 14 or 13 stripes (a white one added on the bottom), so the observation of stripes was close to accurate. Could the same be true of the number of stars? Stars are harder to depict and fit into a small space. But do the four flags depicted with one big star in the upper corner in addition to the array of small ones reflect a real flag used by the fleet?

 

There was a 31-star American flag that had a big white star, but in the middle of a squarish field of 30 smaller ones. The big star represented the recently added state of California. The basic pattern of this flag is the Trumbull Flag, used by the Navy during the War of Independence and from around 1778 to 1880. The original Trumbull pattern was thirteen stars for the original colonies, one star larger and in the middle, seen in Revolutionary War paintings by John Trumbull. This original 13-star pattern is also seen in paintings of American ships of the early and mid-19th century, flying from the mast and flagstaffs.

 

But the flags on the screen do not depict the big star as being in the middle. So, the Japanese image could be an interpretation of the 1853 Commodore Perry flag, which has 31 stars: a square 5x5 grid with a leftmost column of 6, to make up 31. The topmost star on the leftmost column, by standing above the other stars at the top may have seemed unusually prominent, especially rippling in the wind, and thus depicted as larger than the rest. The usual 31-star flag of the time was also arranged in a way that could have had the effect of making the stars at either end of the topmost row seem unusually prominent because they were surrounded by more blue.

 

However, the flags depicted on the Todai screen with one big star have close to 13 smaller ones, and the same pattern of stars and blue space, which leads me to wonder if the Japanese artist is perhaps depicting a variant original Trumbull pattern flag used by the Navy in Perry’s time. The ships are depicted so meticulously that this seems possible. Also, Trumbull flags were often flown from the stern, and this is the case with the four flags here.

text: I never realized how many parts of the ship needed labor.  I just assumed the sails could be furled and unfurled from the deck.

text: The men are dwarfed by the ship. Perhaps this helps to illustrate the technological might wielded by what were seen as otherwise very human (described by the Japanese in ways indicating they were seen as kind, foolish, jovial, etc). The ships are more a part of the landscape, forces of natural power, than they are connected with humanity and its tools.

text: By this point the Japanese are depicting the American ships with more realistic features rather than the fanciful, demonic imagery of the earlier representations. In some ways it's a more dignified view of the fleet, perhaps reflecting the state of relations between Japan and America at the time of the creation of this scroll.

text: The American Flags look like accurate. I am very curious about the depiction of them. As misterspock1 mentioned, they have to have 31 stars (California was the newest state at that time) and 13 stripes even this flag has 14 stripes. The Japanese painters would make them (at least one depiction of a flag) if they knew the history of the “Stars and Stripes”.

text: Seeing the guns firing is really interesting, because as we heard in the video, the Japanese were likely not familiar with the practice of gun salutes.  It's surprising that Perry would fire at all, with the possibility that the shots could be interpreted as attack.

text: The ships are depicted in great detail, they are shown really realistically, and you can also see ships in depth as well as the patterns of the waves formed in the sea around them. But there are no drawings of birds or fish or mammals that should normally show on a realistic drawing. Thus, these drawings show up really detailed and realistic, but they are not made to fill in the curiosity of Japanese; they seem to be made to carefully describe the technological gap they had from Americans at the time when Commodore Perry showed up in Japan. So this looks like an instructive collection of American ships in an attempt to remember them so that they can build their own.

text: As an English student I was surprised to see this unusual arrangement of the stars on the American Flag on what seems to be a well observed and deatiled painting. I was even more surpised to find that many variations were used over time (and not necessarily because of new States joing the Union). The screen uses this arrangement on others ships, is it likely to be correct? If not why not? the artist has clearly observed the fleet.

text:
They couldn't help throwing in a "perfect" profile shot, could they?

This illustration feels much more of a "study" than the others, and also a lot less "free", artistically. The ship is perfectly framed, in near perfect profile, and as far as the ship itself is concerned, there's little sign of "bahaviour".

text:
Is this flag innaccurate, or merely a flag I was no able to find? I attempted to find the flag by searching US Naval flags and other versions of the US flag at the time of his voyage, but was unable to find it.

It seems odd to me because it's so consistently reproduced with this look, and this particular patterning of the stars seems overly complicated for a "misrepresentation" by a foreigner who couldn't accurately reproduce the pattern. Indeed, all patterns I found at this time are simply than this one.

text: This drawing represents the pollution, the contamination caused by US Navy when they came in contact with the Japanese. This contact, for the Japanese, can also be seen as an act of contamination, as they "contaminated" the foreign culture with their costume and may also have altered traditions

text: I like the orientation of the ship in the first panel (from left); it's refreshing to see the view from this angle and to see how precise the detailing is of the paddle wheel from this view.

text: I like the realism of the sailors scurrying about the rigging, doing whatever it is that sailors did on a ship in those days. I like how accurate the rigging looks too, it seems true to form to my untrained eyes.

text: The detail on the paddle-wheel is incredible. I think this is a great example of not only the Japanese curiosity about these ships, but also their artistic attention to detail. Not only is the wheel accurate, it is asthetically pleasing.

text: It's artistic and beautifully drawn but it also feels as a technical study - there is not a missing cable or wire - to understand how it is made, what it does and for the Japanese to build their own... The representation shows technical as well as esthetical admiration but also desire to own the same...

text: The depictions appear more objective now that communication and some understanding between the two contingents have taken place.  Gone are the menacing demonic faces on the bow and stern, the portrayal of evil or threat.  These are impressive ships, yes, but just naval ships with naval staff doing their work.  The detail in illustrating the ropes, masts, those openings on the sides of the ships, the smaller boats, the billowing smoke, and everything really is impressive.  I've enjoyed looking at this row of images in detail.  I notice a couple of seemingly special bright red rowing boats - I wonder why they are red, are they for high ranking officers only?  The lines in the ocean waves and charcoal smoke makes me think how oriental in style it is.  Wonderful illustration.

text: I was surprised by the amount of detail; however, in order to display the most accurate information about the ships and personnel, it was necessary to be detailed. These pictures could be used as references for actual reproduction. The perspective used for the side wheel seems a little "off," but in this way the artist could show more of the important structural detail. The details which were of lesser inportance to the Japanese were not so accurate, as in the case of the American flag.

text: Calm weather all around but for me this feels a bit intimidating owing to the fact that everything is bland. Even the skies, beautiful as they were during a gorgeous Japanese day, is devoid of any clouds or even the regular blue you usually see. Makes the painting seem lifeless but the animation provided by the ships contrasts with the underlying 'quietness' of the images.

text: The blandness of the weather seems deliberate. The pale sky and the barely there blue ocean force the viewer to focus on the ships. The realistic depiction of the ships in the left two panels gives a sense of size, depth and motion of the ships. The third panel (which I agree is probably done by a diff. artist) is a flat rendering but with great detail given to all the ships staff, rigging, masts, etc... To me all these things make me feel that this scroll was probably used for study by scholars and Feudal leaders.

text: The depictions of the paddlewheels seem to change pretty significantly from the initial trip of Perry to this screen. The earlier paddlewheels are very sytlized and impressionistic. These paddlewheels are much more detailed, and you can almost see the artist's mental deconstruction and re-engineering of the them.

text:
It seems to be a picture of the American Black ships leaving. Whether it's their first or second visit is unclear. 

What's interesting is the fact that the American flag is depicted correctly here,in contrast to many other visuals/sketches.

text: 40 men -as crew al least- are shown in the ship. I am sure that the artist knows to sail. He depicted mainly all the functions in a ship by seamen. So, this is a technical drawing -very beautiful and artistically done. And to not confusing the bout’s structure he didn’t depict the sky but he did the wind and sea.

text: Unlike earlier work this depiction lacks the demonic figurheads and other embellishments. The rigging and mastwork is realistically rendered (I like the maritime skills to know if it is accurate). Some details have good consistency, steam billows and multiple flags being wind swept in the same direction, Hollywood sometimes struggles to get those things correct today

text: Interesting to note how, in a few years, Japanese pictorial representations have moved on from being of fantastical smoke-belching demon ships, to drawings of a precise almost technical nature.

text: I think one of the main points about these little sailing figures is scale and number. They are dressed identical, uniform infact, so they aren't individually special people. The size of these ships was a surprise for Japan, and showing the people on them would give the viewer who never saw them themselves a reference point to the size of the ships, and possibly how many could man/contain them.

text: I think it's interesting that, alongside quite good attention to detail, the volume and opacity of the smoke is really overstated. I feel this could be evidence of how surprising such large naval guns were to the japanese artist - they saw bigger clouds than they expected, and subconsciously exaggerated them.

text: Consider the color scheme in the images. How does color contribute to the mood of the illustration? What colors does the illustrator use, and for what purpose? What colors does the illustrator not use?
Lots of people checking the riggings. There's also a commanding officer, looks like good organization.

text: Look at these people here. Why are they there? Why does the illustrator include them? Discuss the depiction of humans in this image. Consider their color, their size, the extent to which they are "realistic," and other factors.

Consider the depiction of the natural environment in which the ships appear. How does the illustrator represent the sky? the sea? flora and fauna? What is the relationship between the ships and the natural world? Why does the illustrator make the choices he does in depicting the natural world, and what message is he trying to convey through these choices?

text: Seems to be much more detail of the water than any background for the ships, which seem to emerge out of thin air, coming from nowhere
Consider and discuss the depiction of flags throughout the image.
Incredible detail work
The amount of detail that went into the drawings indicates that from the moment the ships arrived, artists made sure that engineers were able to reproduce the ships. Or at least the intention
The figures are very tall and thin, maybe to emphasize the american complexion, if we compare with the thickness of a robe left above in the image with almost the same thickness as one of his legs.
Here we can see a lookout sailor managing his telescope to observe the seashore showing how accurate are the depictions
wonderful depiction of watersea, so realistic and delicate
It is remarkable the skill of japanese painters that recreate with great accuracy  the structural framework of masts, ropes, folded sails...
Look at the very detailed painting, no only the smoke, but also the tiny crew climbing all over the parts of the ship
What flag is this, it looks like the 'stars' without the stipes
The overall colour scheme is very pale and insipid, setting a dismal, bleak mood to the event.
So much black smoke gives me the impression of something huge, of power, in this case.
A more realistc and less biased depiction of the americans.
No more demonic faces on the vessels. That's another hint that this was made a few years later!
Is a very realisitic scene. Japanese have time to know americans better. Americans aren't a menace.

The depiction emphasize the impression that this big quantity of smoke produced by the ships caused in the observers, trying to explain the enormous power of this warships and the frightening feeling of risk for the population.

The smoke cloud could represent the most emotionally charged element of the scene. This great dark area outside the steamships could represent the might and danger that the Americans themselves brought to Japan in the form of technology and weaponery.

The black smoky clouds posses emotional strenght as a symbol also in later japanese artwork such as the Raijin & Fuujin folding screen by Tawaraya Soutatsu.
Is this the realistic portrayal of the American Flag at this time?

The depiction of human figures is not as detailed as the technological objetcs, but it serves as a scale to compare the size of the steamships and the size and amount of people that could be carried.

Also the figures depict some of the actions required for maintainance and operation of the stemships, such as mounting, cleaning, releasing and arranging of ropes and sails (as in this corner of the image)
The attention to detail is very interesting. Even on the top we can see people working and the ropes clearly defined. There is a big analytical work behind this painting.

The depictions of sea waves are the most naturallistic representation in the scenes.

I think this is due to the long historic connection for japanese culture to the sea and their developed observation to natural elements; japanese artists use a combination of various lines to depict subtle movement and ripples, as well as the blue nuances of light blue colour and white to create deepness and freshness in a style that is recognizable throughout the entire history of japanese art since the ancient times.
What is this box? It stands out from the black of the ship so strongly.
With how bright and vivid the American flags are compared to everything else, i'd say that they center of attention.
Great attention to detail, to even include stars on the smallest flags here.
No more monsters on the ship, maybe to convey better relations better Japan and America?
A lot of detail going into the ships, as far as showing people up on the sails with their blue sailor outfits and hats.
The ships are no longer being demonized, showing a change in the attitudes of the Japanese peoples towards the Americans.
Wondering what this is (the dark form behind the blue man). Looks to me like it has a head, arms and body, but proportionately it seems too large to be a human figure. Thoughts anyone?
I am amazed at the attention to detail of Japanese artists. Their realism is extraordinary.
As a sailor, I couldnot but notice the exact rendition of the rigging.
Just the attention to detail on  the craftsmanship of the American warships is astounding and provides such a realistic and heavily detailed image.
The sailor's gesture is so accurate and realistic that it is amazingly impressive.
The sketches are not only technical but beautiful as we can feel the wind blowing into the American flag as it float with such elegance.
I love how the Japanese painting are always so detailed that they even included the American flags on each and every ship.
no more flying sailors!

People in uniform working. United to the sea view, this shows Japanese minded realistic pictures with details shown in context. Link to Whitehead organism philosophy and the Japanese "one (i.e. me) in the whole" worldview.

As Musashi said (implied) in Dokkodo, the value of things is to be used by humans. If you paint ships, you paint sailors.

Nothing that fellow students haven't commented yet, but this is a truly impressive piece of art, and I believe it reflects so much of the Japanese character. They truly are a detail-focused, observant people, with a penchant for conveying what they saw in a most refined, sophisticated way.
There are no monsters. This is a sign of better relationships between Japan and America

History aside - as for style, the only thing that makes these ships look Westerners compared to Japanese junks is - confusion.

Japanese found grace in the blackness and equilibrium in the wood-rope net of the ships.
I have been surprised about the way these ships are depicted - we can see every tiny detail in the pictures
People are depicted as disciplined crew members which shows The Japanise respect towards the Americans

The attention to detail is amazing in all of this. I love old ships and the ropes and rigging always seemed gorgeous and complicated. The artwork here acknowledges the complexity of the rigging in a very simple, natural way. I'm impressed.

As an illustrator, I'm realy impresssed by thre use of the paper and transparency to give the impression of a cloudy day in those painting (helped by the lack of shadows). The precise way everything is portrayed, almost technical and simple mood given by that cloudy day make me feel like this scene is more part of what will become "normal" to Japanese.
this drawing is very detailed, makes it very informative.
Artist seems to show scale of the drawing by placing crew members at various points.
In this image, several sailors are placed through the ship in order to emphasise the scale of the vessel

Very accurate and detailed image of complicated and unusual constructions, but... here we can see some perspective failures. Maybe an artist is trying to use some methods of western painters (he might see some pictures during Perry's visit)/ Or the whole thing is too complicated to present it in the usual way.

I found it puzzling that there are 15 stars on the flags in the centre of the painting, 17 on the left and only 9 on the right hand side. US flag never had that amount of stars, and during Perry's misson counted 31 stars.

stark contrast between the flowing, light coloured waves and the stark black bulk of the ship's hull. showing how the boats cut forced nature aside, much like Commodore Perry brushing aside any Japan's desire to maintain self-seclusion through his use of gunboat diplomacy.
the details of the drawings are astonishing
what does this thing represents ? This artwork is very recise and very realistic so but this one thing I can't figure what this is...
There is a cinematic quality to the print as we see one ship recede into distance.  Or does this show total number of ships in the Perry mission?
this boat must be a japanese boat ? It seems to be here to render the size of th steam boat...they are very huge compared to this one !
Great detailed

The technical detail in this screen is very far beyond the detail I have seen in the other depictions of the American ships. It is evident that the artist had a long time to look at the ships and figure out the proportions and placement of everything. It's also impressive to see just how well armed the Perry Expedition was. The array of cannons on this ship is really impressive and I can understand the fear that just looking at this ship would inspire.
In this photo, the American Flag of Star-Spangled Banners looks right. The previous black ship pictures missed the starts.

this is a test
SCENE ONE
Leaving behind the village, a trail winds up into Mount Lingyan. Pleasure-seekers sought out pavilions in the mountain forests.
under the tree, servants with sedan chairs are resting.
What are the three men doing here? What social class do you think they belong to?
SCENE TWO

Here we see a brightly colored sedan chair on a boat. Who do you think is in the chair? What is going on here? Do you notice the musicians in the smaller boat in front of the boat carrying the sedan chair? Think back to Licentiate Yan and what he needed to get musicians for.
In front of the sedan chair carrying boat there is a boat with pennants reading “Hanlin Academy”

Public granaries were established to aid the poor in times of shortage and famine. This particular granary was built between 1723 and 1726. It is surrounded on three sides by water which was convenient for transportation and helped protect it against fire and thieves.
SCENE THREE
Three boats have been pulled together, and a group of fishermen relax together. Note the woman and child on the boat off to the left; a man plays a flute on the opposite end.
SCENE FOUR

Ten Thousand Years Bridge 萬年橋:
One of the many identifiable structures in the scroll, this bridge was constructed in 1740. What types of activity can you see going on on this bridge?
SCENE FIVE
In keeping with the traditional esteem for elder generations, a feast has been sponsored for the older men gathered in the hall.
At the gate, a delivery-man is directed inside.
A bride and groom bow to his parents, as guests arrive at the home.
What are these two little boys doing in one of Suzhou's many gardens?
This district specialized in garden plants and equipment. Can you tell what type of plants are being carried in the boats?

• bbb
This is great analysis!

Artist manipulated neutral colour for background (such as beige, light blue) to remark the black smoke released from the steam boat. More attention is drawn to American flag since the smoke is dense black in contrast to the white, blue, red colour of the flag...It seems to convey the message that the arrival of American boats was not a good sign for Japanese.

the picture is mostly black and white, with some bright red white and blue flags, symbolic of AMERICA, and a bit of red and gold trim on the boats.  Why does a japanese artist emphasize America?  There is not a lot of red in the picture, green is lacking, and many other bright colors.  The black and white and  pale blue water all give the picture a "becalmed" look, as well as foggy.  The thick black smoke emphasizes the presence and power of the steam engines.  Surprisingly, this japanese artist gives most of the color to the American Flag, giving prominence to the symbol of America, and giving it beauty and causing it to draw the eye.  The flags are put on the background of the smoke, which makes them a bit ominous.
Black, obviously, to emphasize the tension between the Japanese and Perry's visit.
The colors of the ships are somber, very serious with the only "color" on the FLAG -- making clear that this is an AMERICAN ship

Apart from the sea and the sky, the main colors are black and white, with a few hints of red and blue. The illustrator is probably concerned with making the most accurate depiction of the scene, not drawing something out of his imagination. His drawing has a documentary value.

The color scheme is very subdued with only the red of the flags and pennants. What I find more striking is the composition. At first glance the mast and spat loom ghostly from the billowing  dark smoke, like an eerie crucifixion figure or otherworldly creature brandishing a US flag in each hand.

The sparing use of the four colors; Red, Blue, Black and Yellow, makes for a very stark, almost encylopedic and techincal depiction of the American vessels. Rather than the more romantizied images of the fleet we saw the American artists creating, the Japanese are capture the structure and detailing of the ship faithfully. The one exception to this the inclusion of the billowing smoke from the gun salute, which does capture the fearsomeness of what that must have looked like and sounded like at the time.
The black of the steam is too visible. The illustrator wanted to remark that.
At first I thought the ship was on fire, but after Professor Dower's comment about the 17 gun salute and by looking more closely at the image, I can see the artillery clearly firing on the left side.

It really seems three color plus the background white. The flags require red and blue and the ships black. Was the color applied with separate blocks requiring precise registration? I would think that a limited number of colors would be much easier and in this case the result is beautiful and powerful.
It provides a contrast between light and darkness, the light being the possible good that comes with technology, the dark, being the bad.

A gun salute. Commodore Perry was always respectful of marine traditions and would put them into practice. At the same time, the Japanese were aware of the power of Perry and of the US Navy and, in this case, terrified by a noise never heard before
I also wondered about the accuracy of the rigging. It seems to me to be very difficult to get that right without considerable experience with sailing ships.
Looks like a housing for the new fangled steam engine. Complete with delicate decorations and a pristine white color.
I think the detail that japanese people used to apply to their drawings helped them to build their own ships.

Good point.  I remember now how paddlewheels in the earlier drawings looked like a kind of Japanese abstract motif (almost floral).  In such a short time the artists have learned to hone in and depict detailed technological aspects of the ships.  The type of gifts received from the American would have seized the imagination of the Japanese people and created such a tech buzz throughout the country. When Prof Dower talked about the quarter size train given by the Americans as a gift, a vision of the contemporary Japanese bullet train flashed through my mind.  I am amazed at how well the Japanese take good ideas from everywhere and make it work best for them, retaining authentic Japanese sensibility on such undertakings.
Is it a bear?
I was wondering the same thing.

This struck me as well. It seems the US flag is inaccurately represented in many of the other images we've seen. I'm not sure why. Perhaps the artists got an impressionistic view of the flags without noticing the details. Though this seems strange considering the careful observation made elsewhere. Perhaps this is just a practical matter. The flags were either flapping in the breeze or hanging limp if there was no wind. This made careful observation of details difficult.
Different author?
From the sounds of it the firing of the other ship was probably a naval salute, in which case the sailors would be out as part of the salute, and to have a look.

I wonder if the high level of detail also comes from Dutch painterly tradition; since Japan was closed off to the West for so long, save for contact with the Dutch, who had a pretty spectacular tradition of painting in incredible detail.

Yes, it must have been exciting for the sailors. I imagine that there would be more displays than on other tours, and it must have been interesting for them to visit a country that had been closed for so long.
One can see the attention to detail which is so typical to Japanese
I was also surprised by the detail with which they've managed to draw the rigging of the ship
Agreed, good example of the Japanese penchant for detail.

I agree they are very useful for scale. The color blue captures the color of the US Navy uniforms of the time, at least as how the Japanese saw them in their formal attire. And though their form is more minimalist they successfully capture the different types of manouvers the men would be doing on the ship and amongst the rigging.

The figures are very carefully observed in what appear to be active poses or certainly poses that capture a sense of their role on the ship.  The colors appear to be closely observed from nature and they are quite realistic.

The people..I see just one person in the segment shown here, on the bow as lookout. He may be measuring depth, or watching the approaching small vessels. In this image, I feel the people are depicted realistically, although simplifed due to the distance of point of observation. (realistically, as opposed to the Japanese kawaraban and sumo drawings..) The degree of detail and accuracy may be due to their role in instruction on the subject matter - these would not be pure decoration, but a form of "Cliffs Notes on Black Ships" for the viewer to study..

Seen from a distance, they all look the same, very thin, wearing the same clothes. They are not drawn in a very realistic way, but seem "realistic" in their behavior, as though the illustrator had very thoroughly observed them while they were working on the ships, perhaps for documentary purpose.
The figures may be slightly larger than life. They still sort of look like performers rather than actual working men.

Only two or three of the flags look to be exactly the same, even though for example the flag on the far right is large enough to allow the same or greater amount of detail as the two together in the center screen. I wonder if this is merely because different artists did the screens, or some quirk in how much room they had to work with. Or, if it has to do with how tricky it probably was to count the stars and stripes on waving flags in the distance on a ship, even if the flag is of huge proportions.

These flags look accuare other flags in other works were not, I think it denotes a bit more thoughtfullnes into the realism of the entire image. (In 1854, there would have been 31 stars, though, but I think they just wanted to show how they were alligned and a close up of how one star looked.)
Both the stripes and stars are inaccurately depicted from a historical viewpoint but that doesn't affect the visual composition. I don't think it was done as a slam
They are useful for the scale

Actually the size of the American flag is probably better close to scale, if you consider the purpose of flying the American colors to identify and annouce clearly as these being American ships and grand visual statement they make. If you are familar with the USS Constitution in the Boston Harbor or any other American Tall Ships, when they are in formal flotila, entering or exiting a harbor the flag they fly is very simalar in size to what these images here depict. I would assume that on the high seas the flag flown would probably be of a more modest size.
I agree that they are carefully drawn in the sense that they indicate the creqpws role on the vessel.
The flags do look huge in scale.  I don't recall seeing Japanese flags, or if so they are much smaller.  I think I need to look more closely!
Very clearly visible and disproportionate in size compared to the vessels
neutral colour is used to depict the presentation of the ships, draw focus on the structure of the ships , their operation and crew's behaviour.
The sky and the sea are monochrome, perhaps to enhance the strikingly detailed drawing of the ships.
This is a very realistic image of the US Navy flag of one of Perry´s ships. Sometimes the Japanese artist invented or imagined it, but this time it seems well copied from the actual one

The sea is represented in a variety of ways, most of them related to the representations seen in traditional wood prints. in the last panel the sea is so stylized as almost to resemble sheets of newspaper spread down. As for the sky: what isn't said often says a lot as do empty spaces in a work of art.

The artist is only interested in the object itself, isolated from its surroundings. In fact, these are only depicted to suggest better how the object works (think the waves). The background color is perfect for the depiction, because it clearly shows all the lines and details of the ship. All in all I would classify these paintings as study works, the object approached almost in a scientific manner. I think we can connect this representation with the curiosity and interest of the Japanese in the Western advancements, not only to learn about them but to build them themselves.
Virtually ignored in favor of the ships and their scale. It it quickly understood what was important in these pictures.
No background is drawn because it is not important. The ships are what are important, and the water is there to show how the ships sit in the water.
It's just the openness of the sea, maybe reflecting the lack of a human civilization, a terra indomita, tabula rasa

The sky appears pink.  Perhaps the illustrator is depicting the ships at dawn with the underlying message that the ships represent a new beginning between the US and Japan.  The is no flora or fauna depicted - only sea and ships.  That fact, combined with the visual of tiny boats juxtaposed with the warships, makes the ships seem incredibly powerful.  If the ships were shown next to majestic scenery, they would have appeared less significant and imposing.

The out of focus 'bokeh' background simply serves to ensure there are no distractions from the focus of the piece, which is the very detailed portrayal of the ships. 
The bubyo is an important piece of furniture in the traditional Japanese room - it is one of the only pieces of funiture, and something like this would surely have served as a focal point for conversation or thought.
Western art of the period was, like western rooms, rather cluttered.

It´s hard for me to tell whether tis is a sunset or a dawn scene, but the soft colours may indicate that the atmosphere is not that hostile, despite the presence of warships. The Japanese at the end were pleased with Perry´s visit.

On the other hand, representation of flora and fauna (not in this picture) usually is very realistic, done with great detail.
I also wondered about the accuracy of the rigging. It seems to me to be very difficult to get that right without considerable experience with sailing ships.

The out of focus 'bokeh' background simply serves to ensure there are no distractions from the focus of the piece, which is the very detailed portrayal of the ships. 
The bubyo is an important piece of furniture in the traditional Japanese room - it is one of the only pieces of funiture, and something like this would surely have served as a focal point for conversation or thought.
Western art of the period was, like western rooms, rather cluttered.
The flags do look huge in scale.  I don't recall seeing Japanese flags, or if so they are much smaller.  I think I need to look more closely!
Looks like a housing for the new fangled steam engine. Complete with delicate decorations and a pristine white color.
At first I thought the ship was on fire, but after Professor Dower's comment about the 17 gun salute and by looking more closely at the image, I can see the artillery clearly firing on the left side.

It´s hard for me to tell whether tis is a sunset or a dawn scene, but the soft colours may indicate that the atmosphere is not that hostile, despite the presence of warships. The Japanese at the end were pleased with Perry´s visit.

On the other hand, representation of flora and fauna (not in this picture) usually is very realistic, done with great detail.

A gun salute. Commodore Perry was always respectful of marine traditions and would put them into practice. At the same time, the Japanese were aware of the power of Perry and of the US Navy and, in this case, terrified by a noise never heard before
This is a very realistic image of the US Navy flag of one of Perry´s ships. Sometimes the Japanese artist invented or imagined it, but this time it seems well copied from the actual one
One can see the attention to detail which is so typical to Japanese
Both the stripes and stars are inaccurately depicted from a historical viewpoint but that doesn't affect the visual composition. I don't think it was done as a slam
Is it a bear?

The color scheme is very subdued with only the red of the flags and pennants. What I find more striking is the composition. At first glance the mast and spat loom ghostly from the billowing  dark smoke, like an eerie crucifixion figure or otherworldly creature brandishing a US flag in each hand.

The artist is only interested in the object itself, isolated from its surroundings. In fact, these are only depicted to suggest better how the object works (think the waves). The background color is perfect for the depiction, because it clearly shows all the lines and details of the ship. All in all I would classify these paintings as study works, the object approached almost in a scientific manner. I think we can connect this representation with the curiosity and interest of the Japanese in the Western advancements, not only to learn about them but to build them themselves.

I wonder if the high level of detail also comes from Dutch painterly tradition; since Japan was closed off to the West for so long, save for contact with the Dutch, who had a pretty spectacular tradition of painting in incredible detail.

The sky appears pink.  Perhaps the illustrator is depicting the ships at dawn with the underlying message that the ships represent a new beginning between the US and Japan.  The is no flora or fauna depicted - only sea and ships.  That fact, combined with the visual of tiny boats juxtaposed with the warships, makes the ships seem incredibly powerful.  If the ships were shown next to majestic scenery, they would have appeared less significant and imposing.

The people..I see just one person in the segment shown here, on the bow as lookout. He may be measuring depth, or watching the approaching small vessels. In this image, I feel the people are depicted realistically, although simplifed due to the distance of point of observation. (realistically, as opposed to the Japanese kawaraban and sumo drawings..) The degree of detail and accuracy may be due to their role in instruction on the subject matter - these would not be pure decoration, but a form of "Cliffs Notes on Black Ships" for the viewer to study..
No background is drawn because it is not important. The ships are what are important, and the water is there to show how the ships sit in the water.
I think the detail that japanese people used to apply to their drawings helped them to build their own ships.

This struck me as well. It seems the US flag is inaccurately represented in many of the other images we've seen. I'm not sure why. Perhaps the artists got an impressionistic view of the flags without noticing the details. Though this seems strange considering the careful observation made elsewhere. Perhaps this is just a practical matter. The flags were either flapping in the breeze or hanging limp if there was no wind. This made careful observation of details difficult.
I was wondering the same thing.

The sparing use of the four colors; Red, Blue, Black and Yellow, makes for a very stark, almost encylopedic and techincal depiction of the American vessels. Rather than the more romantizied images of the fleet we saw the American artists creating, the Japanese are capture the structure and detailing of the ship faithfully. The one exception to this the inclusion of the billowing smoke from the gun salute, which does capture the fearsomeness of what that must have looked like and sounded like at the time.

These flags look accuare other flags in other works were not, I think it denotes a bit more thoughtfullnes into the realism of the entire image. (In 1854, there would have been 31 stars, though, but I think they just wanted to show how they were alligned and a close up of how one star looked.)

Good point.  I remember now how paddlewheels in the earlier drawings looked like a kind of Japanese abstract motif (almost floral).  In such a short time the artists have learned to hone in and depict detailed technological aspects of the ships.  The type of gifts received from the American would have seized the imagination of the Japanese people and created such a tech buzz throughout the country. When Prof Dower talked about the quarter size train given by the Americans as a gift, a vision of the contemporary Japanese bullet train flashed through my mind.  I am amazed at how well the Japanese take good ideas from everywhere and make it work best for them, retaining authentic Japanese sensibility on such undertakings.

I agree they are very useful for scale. The color blue captures the color of the US Navy uniforms of the time, at least as how the Japanese saw them in their formal attire. And though their form is more minimalist they successfully capture the different types of manouvers the men would be doing on the ship and amongst the rigging.
It provides a contrast between light and darkness, the light being the possible good that comes with technology, the dark, being the bad.
Virtually ignored in favor of the ships and their scale. It it quickly understood what was important in these pictures.
Very clearly visible and disproportionate in size compared to the vessels
The black of the steam is too visible. The illustrator wanted to remark that.

Actually the size of the American flag is probably better close to scale, if you consider the purpose of flying the American colors to identify and annouce clearly as these being American ships and grand visual statement they make. If you are familar with the USS Constitution in the Boston Harbor or any other American Tall Ships, when they are in formal flotila, entering or exiting a harbor the flag they fly is very simalar in size to what these images here depict. I would assume that on the high seas the flag flown would probably be of a more modest size.
It's just the openness of the sea, maybe reflecting the lack of a human civilization, a terra indomita, tabula rasa

It really seems three color plus the background white. The flags require red and blue and the ships black. Was the color applied with separate blocks requiring precise registration? I would think that a limited number of colors would be much easier and in this case the result is beautiful and powerful.
They are useful for the scale
Black, obviously, to emphasize the tension between the Japanese and Perry's visit.
Agreed, good example of the Japanese penchant for detail.
I was also surprised by the detail with which they've managed to draw the rigging of the ship

the picture is mostly black and white, with some bright red white and blue flags, symbolic of AMERICA, and a bit of red and gold trim on the boats.  Why does a japanese artist emphasize America?  There is not a lot of red in the picture, green is lacking, and many other bright colors.  The black and white and  pale blue water all give the picture a "becalmed" look, as well as foggy.  The thick black smoke emphasizes the presence and power of the steam engines.  Surprisingly, this japanese artist gives most of the color to the American Flag, giving prominence to the symbol of America, and giving it beauty and causing it to draw the eye.  The flags are put on the background of the smoke, which makes them a bit ominous.
This is great analysis!
I agree that they are carefully drawn in the sense that they indicate the creqpws role on the vessel.

The figures are very carefully observed in what appear to be active poses or certainly poses that capture a sense of their role on the ship.  The colors appear to be closely observed from nature and they are quite realistic.
The colors of the ships are somber, very serious with the only "color" on the FLAG -- making clear that this is an AMERICAN ship

Only two or three of the flags look to be exactly the same, even though for example the flag on the far right is large enough to allow the same or greater amount of detail as the two together in the center screen. I wonder if this is merely because different artists did the screens, or some quirk in how much room they had to work with. Or, if it has to do with how tricky it probably was to count the stars and stripes on waving flags in the distance on a ship, even if the flag is of huge proportions.

Artist manipulated neutral colour for background (such as beige, light blue) to remark the black smoke released from the steam boat. More attention is drawn to American flag since the smoke is dense black in contrast to the white, blue, red colour of the flag...It seems to convey the message that the arrival of American boats was not a good sign for Japanese.

Yes, it must have been exciting for the sailors. I imagine that there would be more displays than on other tours, and it must have been interesting for them to visit a country that had been closed for so long.
neutral colour is used to depict the presentation of the ships, draw focus on the structure of the ships , their operation and crew's behaviour.
Different author?

Seen from a distance, they all look the same, very thin, wearing the same clothes. They are not drawn in a very realistic way, but seem "realistic" in their behavior, as though the illustrator had very thoroughly observed them while they were working on the ships, perhaps for documentary purpose.
From the sounds of it the firing of the other ship was probably a naval salute, in which case the sailors would be out as part of the salute, and to have a look.

The sea is represented in a variety of ways, most of them related to the representations seen in traditional wood prints. in the last panel the sea is so stylized as almost to resemble sheets of newspaper spread down. As for the sky: what isn't said often says a lot as do empty spaces in a work of art.

Apart from the sea and the sky, the main colors are black and white, with a few hints of red and blue. The illustrator is probably concerned with making the most accurate depiction of the scene, not drawing something out of his imagination. His drawing has a documentary value.
The sky and the sea are monochrome, perhaps to enhance the strikingly detailed drawing of the ships.
The figures may be slightly larger than life. They still sort of look like performers rather than actual working men.

target.src: function ( level, x, y ){ //# constants var IIIF_ROTATION = '0', IIIF_QUALITY = 'native.jpg', //## get the scale (level as a decimal) scale = Math.pow( 0.5, this.maxLevel - level ), //# image dimensions at this level level_width = Math.ceil( this.width * scale ), level_height = Math.ceil( this.height * scale ), //## iiif region iiif_tile_size_width = Math.ceil( this.tileSize / scale ), iiif_tile_size_height = Math.ceil( this.tileSize / scale ), iiif_region, iiif_tile_x, iiif_tile_y, iiif_tile_w, iiif_tile_h, iiif_size, uri; if ( level_width < this.tile_width && level_height < this.tile_height ){ iiif_size = level_width + ","; iiif_region = 'full'; } else { iiif_tile_x = x * iiif_tile_size_width; iiif_tile_y = y * iiif_tile_size_height; iiif_tile_w = Math.min( iiif_tile_size_width, this.width - iiif_tile_x ); iiif_tile_h = Math.min( iiif_tile_size_height, this.height - iiif_tile_y ); iiif_size = Math.ceil(iiif_tile_w * scale) + ","; iiif_region = [ iiif_tile_x, iiif_tile_y, iiif_tile_w, iiif_tile_h ].join(','); } uri = [ this['@id'], iiif_region, iiif_size, IIIF_ROTATION, IIIF_QUALITY ].join('/'); return uri; }

text: Look at gueese people here. Why are they there? Why does the illustrator include them? Discuss the depiction of humans in this image. Consider their color, their size, the extent to which they are "realistic," and other facotrs.
Consider2 and discuss the depiction of flags throughout the image.

Consider the depiction of the natural environment in which the ships appear. How does the illustrator represent the sky? the sea? flora and fauna? What is the relationship between the ships and the natural world? Why does the illustrator make the choices he does in depicting the natural world, and what message is he trying to convey through these choices?

text: Consider the color scheme in the photos. How does color contribute to the mood of the illustration? What colors does the illustrator use, and for what purpose? What colors does the illustrator not use?
Interesting to note how, in a few years, Japanese pictorial representations have moved on from being of fantastical smoke-belching demon ships, to drawings of a precise almost technical nature.

text: Unlike earlier work this depiction lacks the demonic figurheads and other embellishments. The rigging and mastwork is realistically rendered (I like the maritime skills to know if it is accurate). Some details have good consistency, steam billows and multiple flags being wind swept in the same direction, Hollywood sometimes struggles to get those things correct today

It seems to be a picture of the American Black ships leaving. Whether it's their first or second visit is unclear.

text: 40 men -as crew al least- are shown in the ship. I am sure that the artist knows to sail. He depicted mainly all the functions in a ship by seamen. So, this is a technical drawing -very beautiful and artistically done. And to not confusing the bout’s structure he didn’t depict the sky but he did the wind and sea.

text: I think it's interesting that, alongside quite good attention to detail, the volume and opacity of the smoke is really overstated. I feel this could be evidence of how surprising such large naval guns were to the japanese artist - they saw bigger clouds than they expected, and subconsciously exaggerated them.

text: I think one of the main points about these little sailing figures is scale and number. They are dressed identical, uniform infact, so they aren't individually special people. The size of these ships was a surprise for Japan, and showing the people on them would give the viewer who never saw them themselves a reference point to the size of the ships, and possibly how many could man/contain them.

text: Calm weather all around but for me this feels a bit intimidating owing to the fact that everything is bland. Even the skies, beautiful as they were during a gorgeous Japanese day, is devoid of any clouds or even the regular blue you usually see. Makes the painting seem lifeless but the animation provided by the ships contrasts with the underlying 'quietness' of the images.

text: I was surprised by the amount of detail; however, in order to display the most accurate information about the ships and personnel, it was necessary to be detailed. These pictures could be used as references for actual reproduction. The perspective used for the side wheel seems a little "off," but in this way the artist could show more of the important structural detail. The details which were of lesser inportance to the Japanese were not so accurate, as in the case of the American flag.

These sailors working on the ship are drawn in details too even though they are minute compared to the ship. Overall i am impressed by the great pain taken to draw the picture. How many days did the artist take to draw the whole ship?

text: The depictions appear more objective now that communication and some understanding between the two contingents have taken place.  Gone are the menacing demonic faces on the bow and stern, the portrayal of evil or threat.  These are impressive ships, yes, but just naval ships with naval staff doing their work.  The detail in illustrating the ropes, masts, those openings on the sides of the ships, the smaller boats, the billowing smoke, and everything really is impressive.  I've enjoyed looking at this row of images in detail.  I notice a couple of seemingly special bright red rowing boats - I wonder why they are red, are they for high ranking officers only?  The lines in the ocean waves and charcoal smoke makes me think how oriental in style it is.  Wonderful illustration.

text: The depictions of the paddlewheels seem to change pretty significantly from the initial trip of Perry to this screen. The earlier paddlewheels are very sytlized and impressionistic. These paddlewheels are much more detailed, and you can almost see the artist's mental deconstruction and re-engineering of the them.

text: Looking through, it is evident that the ships were of greater importance to the artist than the people manning them. That is why there is such minute detail in even the masts and the way the water moves under the boat and its equipment.

text: The sailor's faces and bodies all look the same. They are neither shown in a positive light or negative one. In fact, many of them do not have full faces (obviously because they are too far away to make out any features) but I still find it interesting that they are depicted this way.

text: The blandness of the weather seems deliberate. The pale sky and the barely there blue ocean force the viewer to focus on the ships. The realistic depiction of the ships in the left two panels gives a sense of size, depth and motion of the ships. The third panel (which I agree is probably done by a diff. artist) is a flat rendering but with great detail given to all the ships staff, rigging, masts, etc... To me all these things make me feel that this scroll was probably used for study by scholars and Feudal leaders.

text: All the American boats show lots of industry, many sailors at work. But the scale isn't quite right, so there's a sense that they've been added to emphasize the size of these ships, especially when compared to Japanese ships. It must be the equivalent of an aircraft carrier appearing in Boston Harbor: fascinating, enormous, filled with life, and lots of detail.

text: I thought it was interesting that such detail existed on the ships, yet the flags seemed to be roughly sketched.  The first large flag has 14 strips, and the stars are odd with one larger than the remainder.

text: I like the realism of the sailors scurrying about the rigging, doing whatever it is that sailors did on a ship in those days. I like how accurate the rigging looks too, it seems true to form to my untrained eyes.

text: The detail on the paddle-wheel is incredible. I think this is a great example of not only the Japanese curiosity about these ships, but also their artistic attention to detail. Not only is the wheel accurate, it is asthetically pleasing.

text: This drawing represents the pollution, the contamination caused by US Navy when they came in contact with the Japanese. This contact, for the Japanese, can also be seen as an act of contamination, as they "contaminated" the foreign culture with their costume and may also have altered traditions

They couldn't help throwing in a "perfect" profile shot, could they?

This illustration feels much more of a "study" than the others, and also a lot less "free", artistically. The ship is perfectly framed, in near perfect profile, and as far as the ship itself is concerned, there's little sign of "bahaviour".

text:
Is this flag innaccurate, or merely a flag I was no able to find? I attempted to find the flag by searching US Naval flags and other versions of the US flag at the time of his voyage, but was unable to find it.

It seems odd to me because it's so consistently reproduced with this look, and this particular patterning of the stars seems overly complicated for a "misrepresentation" by a foreigner who couldn't accurately reproduce the pattern. Indeed, all patterns I found at this time are simply than this one.

text: As an English student I was surprised to see this unusual arrangement of the stars on the American Flag on what seems to be a well observed and deatiled painting. I was even more surpised to find that many variations were used over time (and not necessarily because of new States joing the Union). The screen uses this arrangement on others ships, is it likely to be correct? If not why not? the artist has clearly observed the fleet.

text: The American Flags look like accurate. I am very curious about the depiction of them. As misterspock1 mentioned, they have to have 31 stars (California was the newest state at that time) and 13 stripes even this flag has 14 stripes. The Japanese painters would make them (at least one depiction of a flag) if they knew the history of the “Stars and Stripes”.

text: The ships are depicted in great detail, they are shown really realistically, and you can also see ships in depth as well as the patterns of the waves formed in the sea around them. But there are no drawings of birds or fish or mammals that should normally show on a realistic drawing. Thus, these drawings show up really detailed and realistic, but they are not made to fill in the curiosity of Japanese; they seem to be made to carefully describe the technological gap they had from Americans at the time when Commodore Perry showed up in Japan. So this looks like an instructive collection of American ships in an attempt to remember them so that they can build their own.

text: Seeing the guns firing is really interesting, because as we heard in the video, the Japanese were likely not familiar with the practice of gun salutes.  It's surprising that Perry would fire at all, with the possibility that the shots could be interpreted as attack.

text: By this point the Japanese are depicting the American ships with more realistic features rather than the fanciful, demonic imagery of the earlier representations. In some ways it's a more dignified view of the fleet, perhaps reflecting the state of relations between Japan and America at the time of the creation of this scroll.

text: The men are dwarfed by the ship. Perhaps this helps to illustrate the technological might wielded by what were seen as otherwise very human (described by the Japanese in ways indicating they were seen as kind, foolish, jovial, etc). The ships are more a part of the landscape, forces of natural power, than they are connected with humanity and its tools.

text:
Here I was struck by the variation in U.S. flags as depicted on these panels of the screen. 4 flags have a large star in the upper corner and a group of smaller stars, and one flag has uniformly sized stars. Did Perry fly different versions of the U.S. flag or are these just different interpretations of the same flag by the Japanese? The 31-star flag became the official U.S. flag on July 4, 1851, a star having been added to mark the statehood of California (Sept 9, 1850). This 31-star flag was the flag flown for 7 years (1851-1858), so it was the flag Perry sailed under.

 

Japanese images of American flags on the screen show fewer stars, eg., 9 stars, or 16 plus one big star (1), 14 plus one big star (2). There are usually 14 or 13 stripes (a white one added on the bottom), so the observation of stripes was close to accurate. Could the same be true of the number of stars? Stars are harder to depict and fit into a small space. But do the four flags depicted with one big star in the upper corner in addition to the array of small ones reflect a real flag used by the fleet?

 

There was a 31-star American flag that had a big white star, but in the middle of a squarish field of 30 smaller ones. The big star represented the recently added state of California. The basic pattern of this flag is the Trumbull Flag, used by the Navy during the War of Independence and from around 1778 to 1880. The original Trumbull pattern was thirteen stars for the original colonies, one star larger and in the middle, seen in Revolutionary War paintings by John Trumbull. This original 13-star pattern is also seen in paintings of American ships of the early and mid-19th century, flying from the mast and flagstaffs.

 

But the flags on the screen do not depict the big star as being in the middle. So, the Japanese image could be an interpretation of the 1853 Commodore Perry flag, which has 31 stars: a square 5x5 grid with a leftmost column of 6, to make up 31. The topmost star on the leftmost column, by standing above the other stars at the top may have seemed unusually prominent, especially rippling in the wind, and thus depicted as larger than the rest. The usual 31-star flag of the time was also arranged in a way that could have had the effect of making the stars at either end of the topmost row seem unusually prominent because they were surrounded by more blue.

 

However, the flags depicted on the Todai screen with one big star have close to 13 smaller ones, and the same pattern of stars and blue space, which leads me to wonder if the Japanese artist is perhaps depicting a variant original Trumbull pattern flag used by the Navy in Perry’s time. The ships are depicted so meticulously that this seems possible. Also, Trumbull flags were often flown from the stern, and this is the case with the four flags here.

citation: Selections from Mao Zedong, Report on an Investigation of the Hunan Revolutionary Movement (SCT, 406-410)
quote: A rural revolution is a revolution by which the peasantry overthrows the authority of the feudal landlord class. If the peasants do not use the maximum of their strength, they can never overthrow the authority of the landlords, which has been deeply rooted for thousands of years. In the rural areas, there must be a great fervent revolutionary upsurge, which alone can arouse hundreds and thousands of the people to form a great force.

text: Here comes the spiritual resolution with the moon's reflection being the  - albeit wavering - symbol of heavenly love
quote:
The moon and its broken reflection
   And its shadows shall appear,
As the symbol of love in heaven,
   And its wavering image here.

text: The "Yet" is a giveaway here. He now thinks of the woes and miseries of thousands of others who have croossed this bridge, each bearing his burden of sorrows
quote:
Yet whenever I cross the river
   On its bridge with wooden piers,
Like the odor of brine from the ocean
   Comes the thought of other years.   

And I think how many thousands
   Of care-encumbered men,
Each bearing his burden of sorrow,
   Have crossed the bridge since then.   

I see the long procession
   Still passing to and fro,
The young heart hot and restless,
   And the old subdued and slow!   

And forever and forever,
   As long as the river flows,
As long as the heart has passions,
   As long as life has woes;

text: But the mystical magic of the moon and sea starts to work and his cares are now sloughed off into the water
quote:
But now it has fallen from me,
   It is buried in the sea;
And only the sorrow of others
   Throws its shadow over me.

text: This is the low point of the poem - the burden laid upon me seemed greater than I could bear
quote:
For my heart was hot and restless,
   And my life was full of care,
And the burden laid upon me
   Seemed greater than I could bear.

text: And in these 3 stanzas his sadness, misery and then despair are introduced
quote:
A flood of thoughts came o’er me
   That filled my eyes with tears.   

How often, O, how often,
   In the days that had gone by,
I had stood on that bridge at midnight
   And gazed on that wave and sky!   

How often, O, how often,
   I had wished that the ebbing tide
Would bear me away on its bosom
   O’er the ocean wild and wide!

As, sweeping and eddying through them,

And, streaming into the moonlight,
   The seaweed floated wide.

text: A fairly average rhyming structure (every other line corresponding). The host of other devices used (alliteration, assonance, etcetera) create an atmosphere that is very easily recognisable as one of his works. Readers can easily see why Poe is considered such a master of macabre poetry and literature.
quote:
Lo! ’t is a gala night 
   Within the lonesome latter years! 
An angel throng, bewinged, bedight
    In veils, and drowned in tears, 
Sit in a theatre, to see 
  A play of hopes and fears, 
While the orchestra breathes fitfully 
  The music of the spheres.

Mimes, in the form of God on high,
     Mutter and mumble low,
And hither and thither fly—
    Mere puppets they, who come and go
At bidding of vast formless things  
   That shift the scenery to and fro,
Flapping from out their Condor wings 
   Invisible Wo!

That motley drama—oh, be sure 
    It shall not be forgot! 
With its Phantom chased for evermore  
    By a crowd that seize it not, 
Through a circle that ever returneth in  
    To the self-same spot, 
And much of Madness, and more of Sin,  
    And Horror the soul of the plot.

But see, amid the mimic rout,  
    A crawling shape intrude!  
A blood-red thing that writhes from out  
    The scenic solitude!  
It writhes!—it writhes!—with mortal pangs  
    The mimes become its food,  
And seraphs sob at vermin fangs  
   In human gore imbued.

Out—out are the lights—out all! 
    And, over each quivering form, 
The curtain, a funeral pall, 
    Comes down with the rush of a storm, 
While the angels, all pallid and wan,     Uprising, unveiling, affirm 
That the play is the tragedy, “Man,”
    And its hero, the Conqueror Worm.

text: What a wonderful poem! It has a driving rhyme and metere and is written in idiomatic American English, with digressions, repetitions, words in vernacular, just like spoken language: "You see, of course, if you're not a dunce" ..."Just as bubbles do as they burst" ... "Logic is logic. That's all I say"
quote:
- First a shiver, and then a thrill, 
Then something decidedly like a spill, 
And the parson was sitting upon a rock, 
At half-past nine by the meet’n’-house clock, 
Just the hour of the Earthquake shock! 
“something decidedly like a spill”

 -- What do you think the parson found, 
When he got up and stared around? 
The poor old chaise in a heap or mound, 
As if it had been to the mill and ground! 
You see, of course, if you ‘re not a dunce, 
How it went to pieces all at once, 
All at once, and nothing first, 
Just as bubbles do when they burst. 
 “Just as bubbles do when they burst”

End of the wonderful one-hoss-shay. 
Logic is logic. That’s all I say. 
“End of the wonderful one-hoss-shay”

quote:
‘Here’s Cooper, who’s written six volumes to show
He’s as good as a lord: well, let’s grant that he’s so;
If a person prefer that description of praise,
Why, a coronet’s certainly cheaper than bays;
But he need take no pains to convince us he’s not
(As his enemies say) the American Scott.
Choose any twelve men, and let C. read aloud
That one of his novels of which he’s most proud,
And I’d lay any bet that, without ever quitting
Their box, they’d be all, to a man, for acquitting.
He has drawn you one character, though, that is new,
One wildflower he’s plucked that is wet with the dew
Of this fresh Western world, and, the thing not to mince,
He has done naught but copy it ill ever since;
His Indians, with proper respect be it said,
Are just Natty Bumppo, daubed over with red,
And his very Long Toms are the same useful Nat,
Rigged up in duck pants and a sou’wester hat
(Though once in a Coffin, a good chance was found
To have slipped the old fellow away underground).
All his other men-figures are clothes upon sticks,
The derniere chemise of a man in a fix
(As a captain besieged, when his garrison’s small,
Sets up caps upon poles to be seen o’er the wall):
And the women he draws from one model don’t vary.
All sappy as maples and flat as a prairie.
When a character’s wanted, he goes to the task
As a cooper would do in composing a cask;
He picks out the staves, of their qualities heedful,
Just hoops them together as tight as is needful,
And, if the best fortune should crown the attempt, he
Has made at the most something wooden and empty.


‘Don’t suppose I would underrate Cooper’s abilities;
If I thought you’d do that, I should feel very ill at ease;
The men who have given to one character life
And objective existence are not very rife;
You may number them all, both prose-writers and singers,
Without overrunning the bounds of your fingers,
And Natty won’t go to oblivion quicker
Than Adams the parson or Primrose the vicar.


‘There is one thing in Cooper I like, too, and that is
That on manners he lectures his countrymen gratis;
Not precisely so either, because, for a rarity,
He is paid for his tickets in unpopularity.
Now he may overcharge his American pictures,
But you’ll grant there’s a good deal of truth in his strictures;
And I honor the man who is willing to sink
Half his present repute for the freedom to think,
And, when he has thought, be his cause strong or weak,
Will risk t’other half for the freedom to speak,
Caring naught for what vengeance the mob has in store,
Let that mob be the upper ten thousand or lower.

quote:
A revolution is an uprising, an act of violence whereby one class overthrows another. A rural revolution is a revolution by which the peasantry overthrows the authority of the feudal landlord class. If the peasants do not use the maximum of their strength, they can never overthrow the authority of the landlords, which has been deeply rooted for thousands of years. In the rural areas, there must be a great fervent revolutionary upsurge, which alone can arouse hundreds and thousands of the people to form a great force.
